text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
) Due to the move of the ERCS server from Solaris to Linux logins based on the user names are no longer used. The login is now the user’s Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) in lower case letters. (
) Due to the move to Linux access to ERCS is through Active Directory and passwords are no longer used. References to passwords have been removed throughout this IRM. (
) The IRS replaced the Online
(OL
) system with the Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS). References to OL
have been replaced with BEARS throughout this IRM. (
) Due to the move to Linux new BEARS applications for ERCS were created following the BEARS naming conventions. Application names have been updated throughout the IRM. (

) Content from the AIMS/ERCS website was required to be moved to the Virtual Library. ERCS content was moved to the ERCS book under the Exam Systems Knowledge Base. References to the AIMS/ERCS website have been replaced with the ERCS book throughout this IRM.
Due to the move of the ERCS server from Solaris to Linux logins based on the user names are no longer used. The login is now the user’s Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) in lower case letters.
Due to the move to Linux access to ERCS is through Active Directory and passwords are no longer used. References to passwords have been removed throughout this IRM.
The IRS replaced the Online 5081 (OL5081) system with the Business Entitlement Access System (BEARS). References to OL5081 have been replaced with BEARS throughout this IRM.
Due to the move to Linux new BEARS applications for ERCS were created following the BEARS naming conventions. Application names have been updated throughout the IRM.

from the AIMS/ERCS website was required to be moved to the Virtual Library. ERCS moved to the ERCS book under the Exam Systems Knowledge Base. References to the website have been replaced with the ERCS book throughout this IRM.
Signiﬁcant changes to this IRM are reﬂected in the table below:

Original New Description of Change Reference Reference N/A 4.7.2.1.1 “Background”: Added new paragraph, per (3) IRS security requirements, IT employees are not permitted to have access to taxpayer data. N/A 4.7.2.1.6 Added “Deﬁned Terms” in the internal controls section. 4.7.2.2.1 N/A Under “Meeting the Prerequisites” para- (1), graphs pertaining to background checks 4.7.2.2.1 were removed, as all employees undergo (2), a cursory investigation prior to an offer of 4.7.2.2.1 employment. (3),4.7.2.2.1(4) 4.7.2.2.4 N/A Removed “ERCS Login Names and Passwords” as ERCS no longer requires a password, the login name is the user’s SEID in lower case letters, and ERCS no longer has network printers.

Original New Description of Change Reference Reference 4.7.2.2.5 N/A Removed “Changing a Login Name” as the login name is now the user’s SEID in lower case letters. 4.7.2.3.1 4.7.2.3.1 Under “ERCS Employee Records” clariﬁed where the user can ﬁnd assistance when receiving an invalid SEID message when adding a new employee record. 4.7.2.3.2.1 4.7.2.3.2.1 Under “Recommended Permissions” rec- ommendations for SBSE and LB&I Territory Managers was added. 4.7.2.4 4.7.2.4 Under “Getting Assistance” clariﬁed issues must be reported to the local AIMS/ERCS staff to be elevated to the HQ ERCS analysts if the issue cannot be resolved at the local level. OS GetServices tickets should only be input by the HQ ERCS analysts.
Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Some items were reworded for clarity. Also, website addresses and IRM references were reviewed and updated, as necessary.
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE), Large Business and International (LB&I), Tax Exempt & Government Entities (TE/GE) and Headquarters (HQ) employees in Return Preparer Office (RPO), and Whislteblower Office (WO) who use ERCS.

page (
) This IRM section discusses ERCS security and procedures for controlling maintaining ERCS access. (

) Purpose: To provide guidance needed to complete the correct Business En- titlement Access Request System (BEARS) ERCS application and provide recommendation for approval and granting of permissions based upon the user’s official duties. (

) Audience: ERCS is used by employees in SB/SE, LB&I, TE/GE, and Head- quarters (HQ) employees in the Return Preparer Office (RPO), and Whistleblower Office (WO) who monitor inventory, enter examination time, new records or update existing records on ERCS. Employees include managers, technical employees, administrative support personnel and shared administrative support personnel. (
) Policy Owner: The SB/SE Deputy Director, Examination, who is under the SB/SE Director, Examination. (
) Program Owner: SB/SE Director, Technology Solutions. (
) Primary Stakeholders: LB&I. (

) All ERCS users, their managers, and ERCS support personnel (including system administrators, database administrators and ERCS developers) be familiar with this IRM to ensure they are aware of the system security features and the requirements for ERCS access. (

) Users must be aware of the potential for Unauthorized Access of Taxpayer Accounts (UNAX) violations from the use of ERCS. Data from ERCS should accessed only for IRS business purposes. Users should promptly retrieve ERCS reports from printers or fax machines in order to prevent unintentional disclosure. Audit trails are created and subject to review for all user accesses of taxpayer data. For more information about UNAX, see IRM
, IRS authorized Access, Attempted Access or Inspection of Taxpayer Records (UNAX) Program Policy, Guidance, and Requirements.. (

) Per IRS security requirements, IT employees are not permitted to have to taxpayer data. No IT employee should be approved for ERCS access and any user transferred or detailed to an IT position must submit a Remove Access request to have all permission records removed. (
) IRM
, Policy and Guidance, establishes the security program and the policy framework for the IRS. (
) Ensuring the security of ERCS is the responsibility of every user and support personnel including the AIMS/ERCS staff, the ERCS system and database ministrators, and the ERCS developers. (

) ERCS User Responsibilities: All users are responsible for ensuring the security of the ERCS system. This includes but is not limited to the following: • Removing Smart Cards before leaving work stations • Promptly picking up ERCS prints from printers in common areas • Updating and approving work timely and accurately Internal Revenue Manual
ERCS User Responsibilities: All users are responsible for ensuring the security of the ERCS system. This includes but is not limited to the following:
Examination Returns Control System • Protecting taxpayer data from unauthorized access • Reporting security incidences to the proper authorities timely (

) AIMS/ERCS (A/E) Staff Responsibilities: In addition to user the A/E staff security responsibilities include but are not limited to the • Ensuring users have met the prerequisites before approving BEARS requests for ERCS access • Granting user access based on and limited to the user’s official and deleting permission records when no longer needed • Training and/or providing job aids to new users regarding security re- quirements • Ensuring the continued integrity of the ERCS database, which reviewing and correcting data issues and participating in operational reviews based on IRM requirements and local procedures (

) System Administrator (SA) Responsibilities: The ERCS system tor responsibilities include but are not limited to: • Ensuring all security features are installed and operating properly on ERCS server. • Working OS Ge
ervices tickets to resolve ERCS system related issues. (

) Database Administrator (DBA) Responsibilities: The database responsibilities include but are not limited to: • Ensuring all Oracle security features are installed and operating properly. • Working OS Ge
ervices tickets to resolve ERCS database related issues. (

) ERCS creates audit trails for selected changes to returns, employee and permission records. A special audit trail is also created when users taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) or a taxpayer name on ERCS. (

) There are security checks within ERCS to ensure unauthorized users do access programs and authorized users are kept within the boundaries of permissions. These checks are performed automatically and silently each a user attempts to access ERCS. The user has no ability to prevent the checks. (
) See Exhibit
, Acronyms and Deﬁnitions, for acronyms used in the (

quirements Ensuring the continued integrity of the ERCS database, which reviewing and correcting data issues and participating in operational reviews based on IRM requirements and local procedures

Term Deﬁnition • Detail Temporary reassignments to another group or function for less than one year, and is expected to return to the original group. • Acting as a group manager (including the em- ployee’s own group) which involves a change in grade, position, and/or group assignment. • Details out of the Area expected to last one year or less. • Acting Technical employee retains work assignments and inventory, while temporarily acting as manager of their own group. • Manager is on leave or otherwise out of the office. • There is no change of grade or group assign- ment. • Transfer Permanent reassignments to another group or function. • Rotational assignments from one to ﬁve years in length. • Details out of the Area expected to last longer than one year.
• Rotational assignments from one to ﬁve years in length. • Details out of the Area expected to last longer than one year. (
) The following resource documents contain information regarding IRS requirements and ERCS programs related to creating and reading ERCS trails: • IRM
, Policy and Guidance • Security chapter of the ERCS Technical Reference Manual (TRM) • Read Audit Trails section of the Utility Miscellaneous Programs of the ERCS TRM (

) The ERCS book in the Virtual Library contains helpful information to resolve problems and answer questions. The following types of information is avail- able: • Manual and Handbooks - this section contains the ERCS user hand- books and the ERCS TRM. The manuals describe the menu options, screens, reports and other relevant information. • Troubleshooting - this section has information on current issues such installing the ERCS session ﬁle and the Invalid SEID error message. • Contacts - this section contains contact information for AIMS/ERCS Staff, Area and Campus Programs, Employee Group Codes, LB&I tacts, and other helpful contact information. Website. IRM
, Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System, provides further guidelines for the use of statistics by managers and employees.

Examination Returns Control System (ERCS)

) Managers must ensure that employees are only given ERCS access if their requires it. Managers must also ensure access is removed timely when the employee’s job no longer requires ERCS access or the employee is ring from their group. Permission must be restricted so the employee only what is necessary in order to perform official duties. (

) This section discusses the requirements for obtaining and maintaining to ERCS programs and data. The following topics are included: • Meeting the prerequisites • Choosing the BEARS Application • Completing the BEARS Request (
) Employees must have reported to the group before access to ERCS is requested. (

) Employees must have completed a UNAX Brieﬁng and UNAX Certiﬁcation prior to being given access to ERCS data. The employee’s manager is sible for ensuring this has been completed prior to approving the BEARS Access request. (

) Employees hired into a position requiring ERCS access are granted access the approval of their managers and the A/E staff. These positions include: • Exam group managers in SB/SE and their administrative support staff • Team managers in LB&I and their administrative support staff • Territory managers (TM)s and SB/SE Area administrative support staff • Territory managers, Directors of Field Operations (DFO)s, and LB&I Practice Area administrative support staff • Planning and Special Programs (PSP) chiefs, section chiefs, program coordinators, technical employees and their administrative support • Technical Services (TS) managers, selected technical employees and their administrative support staff • Joint Committee Review (JCR) managers and their administrative support staff • National Quality Review System (NQRS) managers and their trative support staff • Quality Review & Analysis (QRA) managers and their administrative support staff • Centralized Case Processing (CCP) managers and selected of their staff • Return Preparer Office (RPO) administrative support staff • A/E managers, analysts, assistants and their administrative support • HQ ERCS analysts Note: An employee detailed into a position above or acting for an employee in a position above, may also be granted access for the duration of the detail acting assignment.
This section discusses the requirements for obtaining and maintaining access to ERCS programs and data. The following topics are included:
Employees hired into a position requiring ERCS access are granted access on the approval of their managers and the A/E staff. These positions include:

Exam group managers in SB/SE and their administrative support staff Team managers in LB&I and their administrative support staff Territory managers (TM)s and SB/SE Area administrative support staff Territory managers, Directors of Field Operations (DFO)s, and LB&I Practice Area administrative support staff Planning and Special Programs (PSP) chiefs, section chiefs, program coordinators, technical employees and their administrative support Technical Services (TS) managers, selected technical employees and their administrative support staff Joint Committee Review (JCR) managers and their administrative support staff National Quality Review System (NQRS) managers and their adminis

trative support staff Quality Review & Analysis (QRA) managers and their administrative support staff Centralized Case Processing (CCP) managers and selected members of their staff Return Preparer Office (RPO) administrative support staff A/E managers, analysts, assistants and their administrative support HQ ERCS analysts

An employee may be granted access on the approval of their manager and an HQ ERCS analyst if there is justiﬁcation that access is needed in order to perform the user’s official duties. These employees include the following:

To obtain access to ERCS, employees must complete a BEARS request. Employees may need to submit more than one request for ERCS access if permission is needed in more than one area or in both LB&I and SB/SE. If the employee requires more than one BEARS request for ERCS, the ﬁrst applica- tion requested must be within the user’s support area and Business Operating Division (BOD). The user should wait until they have accessed ERCS for the ﬁrst time before submitting additional requests to other areas. There is an exception for HQ analysts, NRP analysts, and WO employees. Refer to IRM
) for BEARS procedures for these employees.

) for BEARS procedures for these employees. Note: When an LB&I user needs access to multiple groups within LB&I, of PBC, only one BEARS request is needed. It should be for the area that supports the user’s home group. (

) ERCS users are supported by the A/E staff located in the user’s local area CCP campus, with the exception of employees in Fraud/Bank Secrecy Act (BSA),Withholding Exchange and International Individual Compliance and WO employees. Fraud/BSA, WEIIC, and RPO users have their own A/E support staff. WO employees are supported by Area
, Western. Refer to the AIMS-ERCS Staff Listings for support contact information. (

) It is important to select the correct BEARS ERCS application because each one is routed to the local A/E staff for approval, creation of the user’s ERCS employee record, work schedule proﬁle and inputting permission records. ERCS BEARS Application tables, Exhibit
through Exhibit

, include all ERCS applications for requesting access. Except for HQ analysts, NRP analysts, and WO employees, the exhibit tables should be used to determine a user’s initial BEARS application selection. For the excepted employees refer to IRM

) On rare occasions if access is needed to update records for an additional or BOD, subsequent BEARS requests must be completed. Write permission across areas requires justiﬁcation in the Special Instructions box on the request. (

) HQ analysts, NRP analysts, and WO employees must have an approved BEARS request for PROD ANALYST ERCS HQ ANALYST prior to any other ERCS BEARS application. This ERCS application is routed to the HQ ERCS analysts for approval. An HQ ERCS analyst will contact the employee or employee’s manager to determine what level of access and mission records are needed, and then will inform the employee which subsequent BEARS ERCS application to submit. The HQ ERCS analyst will alert the A/E managers in the areas impacted to let them know that ERCS access has been granted. (
) Information for BEARS applications for Statistical Sampling Inventory Listing (SSIVL), Tableau and A/E staff are discussed in IRM
, AIMS/

ERCS users are supported by the A/E staff located in the user’s local area or CCP campus, with the exception of employees in Fraud/Bank Secrecy Act (BSA),Withholding Exchange and International Individual Compliance (WEIIC), and WO employees. Fraud/BSA, WEIIC, and RPO users have their own A/E support staff. WO employees are supported by Area
, Western. Refer to the AIMS-ERCS Staff Listings for support contact information.
Information for BEARS applications for Statistical Sampling Inventory Validation Listing (SSIVL), Tableau and A/E staff are discussed in IRM 4.7.10, AIMS/
Examination Returns Control System (ERCS)
ERCS Staff. See Headquarters Contacts for AIMS, ERCS, SETTS, SSIVL, Tableau for contact information for the HQ analysts who support these programs. (

) BEARS requests for new users must contain sufficient information for the analyst to add the employee’s permission records on ERCS as this the BEARS serves as the official record of the user’s approved level of access. The following information must be included in the Special Instructions box, the employee, the employee’s manager, or the A/E analyst: a. User’s login, this will be the employee’s SEID with lower case letters. b. AIMS Assignee Code (AAC) or AACs - The Primary Business Code (PBC), Secondary Business Code (SBC), and Employee Group (EGC) combination the user needs permission for in order to run update records, apply time, etc. These three codes make up the

AAC. c. Permission type - The permission types consist of read, write, ﬁrst approval, and second level approval. With read permission users can reports and see returns in their group. Write permission gives the the ability to generate forms, update returns, and add or update employee records in the group. First level approval permission gives managers and acting managers the ability to approve updates made other users in the group. In general, administrative support are given read and write permission, managers are given read and level approval permission and TMs are given read and second level approval permission. Note: Acting managers with inventory will not routinely be given write mission during an acting assignment and must not be given permanent write permission. Users requesting temporary write mission should include the requested permission in the Special Instructions box and the reason it’s needed, when completing modifying) their BEARS request so it is included when the
ERCS Staff. See Headquarters Contacts for AIMS, ERCS, SETTS, SSIVL, and Tableau for contact information for the HQ analysts who support these programs.

the employee, the employee’s manager, or the A/E analyst: a. User’s login, this will be the employee’s SEID with lower case letters. b. AIMS Assignee Code (AAC) or AACs - The Primary Business Code (PBC), Secondary Business Code (SBC), and Employee Group Code (EGC) combination the user needs permission for in order to run reports, update records, apply time, etc. These three codes make up the

digit AAC. c. Permission type - The permission types consist of read, write, ﬁrst level approval, and second level approval. With read permission users can run reports and see returns in their group. Write permission gives the user the ability to generate forms, update returns, and add or update employee records in the group. First level approval permission gives managers and acting managers the ability to approve updates made by other users in the group. In general, administrative support employees are given read and write permission, managers are given read and ﬁrst level approval permission and TMs are given read and second level approval permission. Note: Acting managers with inventory will not routinely be given write per- mission during an acting assignment and must not be given permanent write permission. Users requesting temporary write per- mission should include the requested permission in the Special Instructions box and the reason it’s needed, when completing (or modifying) their BEARS request so it is included when the manager approves the form. Note: Managers may be given write permission, temporary is preferable, with TM approval. The manager must include the requested permis- sion in the Special Instructions box and the reason write permission is needed, when completing (or modifying) their BEARS request so it is included when the TM approves the form. The BEARS request must be approved by the TM and not by proxy. Note: Territory managers must approve requisitions, statute updates, and transfers or closures to a return generating the command code AMSOC if made by a manager in their territory. Since an acting manager cannot approve work for returns in their own inventory, the TM may need to approve updates made to the acting manager’s inventory. Therefore, if a TM approves write permissions for a manager or acting manager, they must be an active ERCS user with second level approval. d. User Type - (Group, PSP, Review (Technical Services), Sample Review, CCP, Territory, DFO, Area, Admin, Limited). The user type determines the menu options available to the user.

Note: Acting managers with inventory will not routinely be given write mission during an acting assignment and must not be given permanent write permission. (Group, PSP, Review (Technical Services), Sample Review, CCP, Territory, DFO, Area, Admin, Limited). The user type determines menu options available to the user.

Note: Territory managers must approve requisitions, statute updates, and transfers or closures to a return generating the command code AMSOC if made by a manager in their territory. Since an acting manager cannot approve work for returns in their own inventory, the TM may need to approve updates made to the acting manager’s inventory. Therefore, if a TM approves write permissions for a manager or acting manager, they must be an active ERCS user with second level approval.
Example: A user acting for the manager on an ongoing basis may need permanent access to the server, but temporary permission to approve work during each acting assignment.
Justiﬁcation

The business reason the employee needs access must be included in the Special Instructions box. If permission is needed outside the user’s group or function, a justiﬁcation must be input. Any other special instructions should be included such as detail assignment or acting assignment.
Note: Except for Limited Access users, examiners access to should be restricted to acting assignments.

) In addition to numerous program validation and consistency checks to data is valid, ERCS security is assured by: • Limited system and data access by users to ensure information is provided on a need-to-know basis. • Audit trail generation and review of users’ activities. • Electronic managerial approval of certain actions. (
) The following topics are included in this section: • ERCS Employee Records • Permissions • Employee Audit Security • Audit Trails • Audit Trail Review (

) ERCS interfaces with the Corporate Authoritative Directory Service download employee information, including the employee’s SEID, into the ERCS database. Only data for SB/SE, LB&I, WO, and RPO employees is downloaded. When an employee record is added to ERCS, the user employee’s SEID. It is validated against the downloaded employee data CADS (Discovery Directory). If a user is unable to add a new employee to ERCS because the employee’s SEID is invalid, the user should refer to instructions on the Invalid SEID Error Message page under the ERCS book to resolve the issue. (
) Employee records are added by a user with write permission for the AAC employee will be assigned to. This includes administrative support staff or local A/E staff.
(10-11-2019) Security Features of ERCS

ERCS interfaces with the Corporate Authoritative Directory Service (CADS) to download employee information, including the employee’s SEID, into the ERCS database. Only data for SB/SE, LB&I, WO, and RPO employees is downloaded. When an employee record is added to ERCS, the user enters the employee’s SEID. It is validated against the downloaded employee data from CADS (Discovery Directory). If a user is unable to add a new employee to ERCS because the employee’s SEID is invalid, the user should refer to the instructions on the Invalid SEID Error Message page under Troubleshooting in the ERCS book to resolve the issue. Employee records are added by a user with write permission for the AAC the employee will be assigned to. This includes administrative support staff or the
Employee records are added by a user with write permission for the AAC the employee will be assigned to. This includes administrative support staff or the
Examination Returns Control System (ERCS)
Examination Returns Control System (

) The information on the ERCS employee record should be entered accurately and completely. Any changes to the record should be updated as soon as are known. ERCS employee record data is used to: • Verify a user is authorized to access ERCS. • Determine if an employee is required to charge technical time. • Validate the employee’s AAC during inventory assignment. • Determine if the employee should have access to the Managerial Approval menu option. • Determine if an employee’s actions require managerial approval. • Protect an employee’s tax return from unauthorized access. • Determine who should receive employee audit security alerts. • Determine if the employee’s tax return can be audited in the area. • Create ERCS audit trails. • Create the SETTS ﬁle. (

) Employee records should be updated when an employee’s name changes. If an employee has been issued a pseudonym for security reasons, the pseudonym should be entered on the ERCS employee record followed by a space and the literal XX. This will alert the A/E staff that the name on the employee record is not the employee’s real name. (

) ERCS employee records should be inactivated when the employee leaves IRS or transfers within the IRS to a non-ERCS position. If the employee’s is entered on ERCS, the end date on the employee record must be set to the last day the employee is required to enter time. Otherwise, the last day the employee worked should be entered for the employee’s end date. The login name should not be removed from the ERCS employee record when an employee record is inactivated. It is a link to the ERCS audit trails. (
) A user’s login must be entered in the Login ﬁeld of the employee record or user will not be able to access ERCS. (

) Permission records determine what menu options are available to a user the ERCS Main Menu. They also give users the ability to run reports, update employee records and returns, input time, and approve work. (
) Permission records are to be added when a BEARS request is processed or the user will not be able to access ERCS. (

) The permission types are read, write, ﬁrst level approval, and second level approval. Managerial approval can be restricted so the user can only updates by return. Permission records are based on AACs. For example, a group manager may be given read and ﬁrst level approval permission for the group’s AAC. A CCP user in Memphis may be given read and write for returns in Memphis CCP. (

) ERCS programs use the employee’s permission records with the ERCS national status code ﬁles to restrict access based on the status code on the return. For example, a group user may only update returns in a group status. CCP users may only update returns in a CCP status. See Document
, Examination Division Reporting System Codes Booklet, for a list of status codes used by examination. (
) Permission records are added by the A/E staff. Managers with permanent level approval permission can delegate temporary ﬁrst level approval permis- Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
C

Determine if the employee should have access to the Approval menu option. Determine if an employee’s actions require managerial approval. Protect an employee’s tax return from unauthorized access. Determine who should receive employee audit security alerts. Determine if the employee’s tax return can be audited in the Create ERCS audit trails. Create the SETTS ﬁle.

ERCS employee records should be inactivated when the employee leaves the IRS or transfers within the IRS to a non-ERCS position. If the employee’s is entered on ERCS, the end date on the employee record must be set to the last day the employee is required to enter time. Otherwise, the last day the employee worked should be entered for the employee’s end date. The login name should not be removed from the ERCS employee record when an

Permission records determine what menu options are available to a user within the ERCS Main Menu. They also give users the ability to run reports, update employee records and returns, input time, and approve work.
Permission records are added by the A/E staff. Managers with permanent ﬁrst level approval permission can delegate temporary ﬁrst level approval permis-

sion for their group to an acting manager as long as the employee has an active ERCS login. Approval permission should only be granted for the of the acting assignment. Managers with permanent write permission may delegate temporary write permission for their group to a shared support employee in another group if assistance is needed. (
) For permanent permission changes within the same area and temporary changes lasting over
days, the user is required to submit a Modify request via BEARS. (
) Permission can be permanent or temporary. Temporary permission is for up to
days, if needed for a longer period of time, permanent should be granted. The user will request removal of the permission records a Remove Access BEARS request when no longer needed. (

) A temporary, emergency permission change within the same area may be granted by the user’s local A/E analyst. The request should be made by agement via e-mail. For emergency permission not covered in these instructions, contact an HQ ERCS analyst. (

) If an employee acts for their manager, ﬁrst level approval permission will be granted with a beginning date and an ending date covering the acting ment. If the acting assignment ends early, and permission was delegated by the group manager, the manager will update the permission records to the correct end date, but the ERCS employee record will remain active. When an employee record is inactivated, the ERCS program updates the ployee’s permission records to end on the employee’s inactivation date. If a user no longer needs ERCS access due to a change in position or a Remove Access BEARS request must be input. If a user is suspended from active duty the manager must input a Remove Access BEARS request for the user’s ERCS access if one isn’t systemically generated. Access to Menu Options

permission in order to transfer cases to other LB&I groups in a different Practice Area. ) Department managers in CCP need read permission for the CCP campus, may be given second level approval permission, as needed. (

) Territory managers in TS may be given Review read, ﬁrst level and second level approval permission, as needed. (
) Sample review managers and administrative support staff need read and for their sample review AACs. (

) An employee audit occurs when the tax return of an IRS employee is (

) examined. ERCS provides special security features for employee returns Employee Audit Security audit. When any of the following events occur an audit trail is created and ERCS system email alert is generated: • A user enters their own Social Security Number (SSN) or the SSN of spouse (if a joint return was ﬁled) • The source code on a return is changed to or from Source Code

, “Employee Return” • The “Employee Audit” indicator is turned on or off on a return • An unauthorized user attempts to access an employee’s return • A user attempts to add an employee return to ERCS for an employee who should not be audited in the same area • A employee’s return is on AIMS and during AIMS to ERCS the program attempts to add the return to ERCS in an area where employee should not be audited • The addition of a high proﬁle employee return to ERCS (such as the Security Officer) (
) If there is a Security Officer with ERCS access for the area, the employee audit e-mail is sent to the Security Officer. Otherwise, the ERCS system is sent to the PSP TM. See IRM
, Planning and Special Programs for more information about the employee audit email. Note: ERCS system email is sent and received on the ERCS server. (

) Not all employee audit alerts are an indication the user is doing something appropriate. An employee audit occurs when the tax return of an IRS employee is examined. ERCS provides special security features for employee returns under audit. When any of the following events occur an audit trail is created and an ERCS system email alert is generated:
A user enters their own Social Security Number (SSN) or the SSN of spouse (if a joint return was ﬁled) The source code on a return is changed to or from Source Code

, “Employee Return” The “Employee Audit” indicator is turned on or off on a return An unauthorized user attempts to access an employee’s return A user attempts to add an employee return to ERCS for an employee who should not be audited in the same area A employee’s return is on AIMS and during AIMS to ERCS the program attempts to add the return to ERCS in an area where employee should not be audited The addition of a high proﬁle employee return to ERCS (such as the Security Officer)
If there is a Security Officer with ERCS access for the area, the employee audit e-mail is sent to the Security Officer. Otherwise, the ERCS system email is sent to the PSP TM. See IRM
, Planning and Special Programs (PSP), for more information about the employee audit email.

If there is a Security Officer with ERCS access for the area, the employee audit e-mail is sent to the Security Officer. Otherwise, the ERCS system email is sent to the PSP TM. See IRM 4.7.5, Planning and Special Programs (PSP), for more information about the employee audit email.
Note: ERCS system email is sent and received on the ERCS server.
Not all employee audit alerts are an indication the user is doing something in

appropriate. For example, alerts may be generated when a user accesses an employee’s return by taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN), and the program ﬁnds one tax period assigned to the user’s group and one tax period controlled in another group or function. An alert will be generated for the tax period that is not in the user’s group. Some alerts are an indication of inappropriate access,

Examination Returns Control System for example, when a user enters their own SSN. See Employee Audits Codes and Procedures in the ERCS book for more information. Note: When an employee performs a search using the taxpayer’s name and the name or name control entered matches any IRS employee, audit trails are created for each matched employee. Entering as much of the taxpayer’s name as possible reduces the risk of matching an employee. (

) Employee returns are not included on ERCS reports and screens if the user not authorized to see the data. In general, this means the user must have mission to the AAC of a return before the return information may be viewed, regardless of the status code. Users are not notiﬁed when an employee alert is generated for their access. (
) For more information about employee audit security features refer to the rity chapter of the ERCS TRM. (

) An ERCS audit trail is a record of an event initiated by a user or program the ERCS server. The event can be anything from execution of a program accessing or changing data. Audit trails can be used to research when changes were made to data, and to determine who input or approved the changes. Audit trails can also detect potential unauthorized access or suspi- cious activities. (

) ERCS captures audit trail information for the following events: • Addition or deletion of taxpayer records • Modiﬁcation and managerial approval for selected updates to return formation • Research of taxpayer records • Addition of employee records • Modiﬁcation of selected employee information • Addition, deletion or modiﬁcation of ERCS permissions • User access to the ERCS Main Menu • Selected events regarding employee returns under audit (

) The event information captured in an ERCS audit trail includes, but is not limited to the following: • Time and date of the event • User identiﬁcation • Approver’s identiﬁcation, if the action required approval • Type of activity (add, update, research, etc.) • Data that was accessed or changed • Program that was executed (

) Audit trail information may be accessed from special ERCS menus by A/E analysts, HQ ERCS analysts, and designated system security officers. Managers should consult their local A/E staff for assistance if information an ERCS audit trail is needed. For more information about ERCS audit refer to the “Read Audit Trails” section of the Utility Miscellaneous Programs chapter of the ERCS TRM. For information about the responsibilities of the staff regarding the ERCS audit trails, see IRM
, AIMS/ERCS Staff. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
C

When an employee performs a search using the taxpayer’s name and the name or name control entered matches any IRS employee, audit trails are created for each matched employee. Entering as much of the taxpayer’s name as possible reduces the risk of matching an employee.

Audit trail information may be accessed from special ERCS menus by A/E analysts, HQ ERCS analysts, and designated system security officers. ) All modernized IRS systems containing taxpayer data, like ERCS, are to send their system and program audit trails to the Security Audit and Review System (SAAS). Audit trail repositories like SAAS aid the IRS and TIGTA in detecting potential unauthorized accesses to IRS systems and data. (

) Security specialists from Cybersecurity are responsible for performing the review of audit trails sent to SAAS. Reports from SAAS are also sent to the HQ ERCS analysts for review and veriﬁcation that accesses are business related. (
) Refer to IRM
, IT Security Roles and Responsibilities, for more tion including actions to take for suspected security incidents. (

) Users experiencing ERCS program problems or questions are to seek tance from their local A/E staff. If the local staff cannot resolve the user’s they will elevate to the HQ ERCS analysts. If the HQ ERCS analysts resolve the issue it will be elevated to the ERCS developers. The ERCS opers make the determination if an OS Ge
ervices ticket needs to be and the HQ ERCS analysts input the ticket. Tickets should not be input by A/E staff or end-users. (

) For information on current issues impacting ERCS refer to the section of the ERCS book. For information on current changes or updates pacting ERCS refer to the What’s New section of the ERCS book. (
) For information on running the ERCS programs or on error messages running ERCS, refer to the ERCS User Handbooks in the Manual and books section of the ERCS book.
